Modern Physics Letters A
Vol. 30, No. 6 (2015) 1550029 (8 pages)
c
World Scientific Publishing Company
DOI: 10.1142/S0217732315500297
Degeneracy pressure of noncommutative fermions
S. Heydarnezhad * and M. Soudmand
Department of Physics, Payame Noor University,
P. O. Box 193953697, Tehran, Iran
* sevda.heydarnezhad@live.com
Received 28 July 2014
Revised 13 November 2014
Accepted 15 December 2014
Published 6 February 2015
The free energy of an imperfect gas of nonrelativistic fermions in noncommutative space
is calculated to 2-loop order and its zero and low temperature limits are derived. Impli-
cations on the degeneracy pressure of the system is discussed.
Keywords: Noncommutative space; imperfect fermion gas; 2-loop degeneracy pressure.
PACS Nos.: 03.70.+k, 11.10.Nx
text.body:
1. Introduction
In recent years, there has been a growing interest in the noncommutative (NC)
theories of spacetime. Motivated by the theoretical considerations in high energy
physics, specifically string theory and quantum gravity, NC theories assume a non-
commutative algebra for the space (or spacetime) coordinates x i (i = 1, 2, 3), by
demanding
1
[ˆ x i , ˆ
x j ] = iθ ij ,
(1)
where θ ij assumed to be a constant antisymmetric matrix. Another motivation to
consider a NC algebra for the coordinate of particles is the so-called Barry curvature
of the band structure in certain materials.
2,3 In a NC space, one replaces the product
of the fields with the so-called star-product defined to be
1
φ 1 (ˆ x) φ 2 (ˆ x) ≡ lim
x→y
exp
i
2
θ ij ∂ xi ∂ yj
φ 1 (x)φ 2 (y) ,
(2)
where φ 1 and φ 2 are some fields defined in NC space. Here, a summation over
repeated indices is assumed. The left-hand side of above relation is the product of
two fields in a NC space. The right-hand side is the product of the field in usual

(3)
This entails that the kinetic part of the Hamiltonian will not be affected by the
noncommutativity of space, which means that the noncommutativity appears only
in the interactions. Using Eq. (2), one can easily show that for plane waves e

and e

(5)
The noncommutativity parameter could be related to the vector θ = (θ 1 , θ 2 , θ 3 ) by
means of the antisymmetric Levi-Civita tensor ijk , via θ ij =
1
2 ijk θ k , giving rise

p ∧ p

1
2
θ · p × p
.
(6)
The change in the energy spectrum of the imperfect fermions and electron gas due
to the noncommutativity of space was discussed by some authors.
4–6 In more recent
studies, possible implications of the NC algebra on the BCS energy gap and Fermi
liquid are investigated.
7,8 All of the above-mentioned studies are zero temperature
models. Here, our main goal is to generalize the studies of Refs. 5 and 6 to the case
of finite temperate using the formalism of finite temperature many-body problem.
In this paper, we shall consider an imperfect gas of nonrelativistic fermions
defined in a NC space at nonzero temperature and shall derive its free energy
to second order in the noncommutativity parameter. As another feature of the
model, we discuss the implications of noncommutativity of space on the degeneracy
pressure of the gas at finite temperature and derive its low and zero temperature
limits. At zero temperature, our result for the free energy coincides with the ground
state energy of Ref. 6.

fermions has the form

3. 2-loop Free Energy in NC Space
As relation (3) implies, in NC space only the the interaction part of the Hamiltonian
equation (9) is influenced by the noncommutativity of space. From Eq. (2), we write
H int =
g
2

contribution from the noncommutativity. Therefore, only the 2-loop contribution
to the free energy is affected by the noncommutativity of space. We denote the free

noncommutativity of space.

The first term of this formula is the well-known degeneracy pressure of a zero

Inspecting Eqs. (31) and (35) reveals that at low temperature, dependence of the
free energy and the degeneracy pressure on the temperature and noncommutativity
parameter is of the same order. So, at T = 0 the noncommutativity parameter may
be interpreted as new reference temperature.
4–6
6. Conclusion
In this paper, we considered the effect of space noncommutativity on the free en-
ergy of the self-interacting fermions at finite temperature. We obtained a correction
on the degeneracy pressure due to the noncommutativity of space at low and zero
temperature limits. We argued that the the pressure is increased by a factor pro-
portional to second-order in noncommutativity parameter.
